Description: Honeywell International Inc. pleaded guilty in federal district court in Benton, Ill., to one felony offense for knowingly storing hazardous waste without a permit in violation of the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA). Honeywell was also sentenced to pay a criminal fine in the amount of $11.8 million.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department
Info Source: http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/honeywell-pleads-guilty-illinois-illegal-storage-hazardous-waste

Description: A settlement with Honeywell International Inc. estimated to be worth more than $10 million will ensure that cleanup of the remaining areas of the Allied Chemical and Ironton Coke Superfund Site in Ironton, Ohio, will move forward, the Justice Department and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) announced.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department
Info Source: http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/settlement-reached-allied-chemical-and-ironton-coke-superfund-site-ohio

Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2006/June/06_civ_370.html

Description: Honeywell Resins and Chemicals LLC agreed to pay a $3 million civil penalty for alleged Clean Air Act violations at its Hopewell, Va., plant, and improve the facility's air pollution control equipment and processes. In addition to the $3 million civil penalty, Honeywell agreed to reduce harmful air pollutants, install selective catalytic reduction at four production trains at the facility, conduct a third-party benzene waste operations audit, and implement an enhanced leak detection and repair program at the facility.  Honeywell also agreed to perform a mitigation project valued at approximately $1 million at the facility. The settlement reduced annual emissions of NOx by about 6,260 tons, and cut annual emissions of benzene, other VOCs and hazardous air pollutants by 100 tons.  The estimated cost for injunctive relief to address these emissions was approximately $66 million.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department
Info Source: http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/honeywell-resins-and-chemicals-pay-3-million-penalty-upgrade-air-pollution-controls-hopewell

Description: Honeywell Resins and Chemicals LLC agreed to pay a $3 million civil penalty (divided equally between the United States and the Commonwealth of Virginia) for alleged Clean Air Act violations at its Hopewell, plant, and agreed to  improve the facility's air pollution control equipment and processes.
Info Source: https://www.deq.virginia.gov/permits-regulations/enforcement/final-orders

Description: Honeywell agreed to pay $333,370 in settlement of allegations its chemical production facility violated its air emission permits for sulfuric acid and NOx.
Info Source: https://www.deq.virginia.gov/permits-regulations/enforcement/final-orders
https://www.deq.virginia.gov/permits-regulations/enforcement/final-orders

Description: Honeywell agreed to pay $363,542 in settlement of allegations its chemical production facility violated its air emission permits by not being able to provide records, reporting erroneous NOx emissions, and failing to obtain production permits.
Info Source: https://www.deq.virginia.gov/permits-regulations/enforcement/final-orders

Description: $150,000 fine and $772,000 for supplemental environmental projects
Info Source: Honeywell Agrees to Settle, Richmond Times Dispatch, December 1, 2001 (via Nexis).

Description: Honeywell International, Inc. settled allegations that it violated the International Traffic in Arms Regulations (ITAR) in connection with unauthorized exports and retransfers of technical data resulting from the failure to exercise appropriate internal controls.
Agency: State Department Directorate of Defense Trade Controls
Info Source: https://www.pmddtc.state.gov/sys_attachment.do?sysparm_referring_url=tear_off&view=true&sys_id=9d3eab0b1bb764902dc36311f54bcb3f

Description: Saint-Gobain Performance Plastics, Honeywell International and 3M agreed to pay a total of $65.25 million to settle litigation alleging they were responsible for contamination of the water supply of Hoosick Falls, New York with firefighting foam containing perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA), also known as a forever chemical. The parties did not disclose how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided evenly among them.
Private Litigation Case Title: Baker et al v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plastics Corp. et al
Info Source: https://www.law360.com/articles/1462104/-65m-new-york-forever-chemical-water-suit-gets-final-ok
http://adem.alabama.gov/compInfo/2021orders.pdf

Company: National Technology and Engineering Solutions of Sandia, LLC
Info Source: https://www.energy.gov/sites/default/files/2021-05/Settlement%20Agreement%20Transmittal%20Letter%2C%20National%20Technology%20and%20Engineering%20Solutions%20of%20Sandia%2C%20LLC.pdf

Description: Discharges of chromium and other metals.
Private Litigation Case Title: Halley et al v. Honeywell International, Inc. et al
Info Source: https://www.law360.com/articles/795130

Description: Honeywell agreed to pay $5.36 million to settle its portion of a class action in which it and Siemens were sued for contaminating the water supply of Urbana, Ohio.
Private Litigation Case Title: Bentley, et al v. Honeywell International, et al
